frontmatter.title: Why ASTR 596 is Designed This Way

children.value: This course intentionally operates differently from traditional lecture-based classes because
research careers require fundamentally different skills
than undergraduate coursework. Understanding why we use this approach will help you get the most from the experience.
What Professional Technical Work Actually Looks Like

children.label: What Professional Technical Work Actually Looks Like

children.value: Whether you pursue academia, industry, or entrepreneurship, high-level technical work shares common characteristics:
: You’re solving problems no one has tackled before
: Managers expect solutions, not step-by-step guidance requests
: Standard methods often need adaptation for new contexts
: Working effectively with colleagues at your skill level
: Strategic use of computational tools is now standard across industries
: Technology evolves rapidly; successful professionals adapt continuously
: Real problems don’t respect academic boundaries
The Transition from Student to Scientist

children.label: The Transition from Student to Scientist

children.value: As Martin Schwartz explains in his influential essay,
the transition from coursework to research is jarring by design
: Taking courses, getting right answers on tests, feeling smart when you know the answers
nobody knows the right answers yet
: As Schwartz discovered when even his Nobel Prize-winning advisor didn’t know how to solve a research problem:
“That’s when it hit me: nobody did. That’s why it was a research problem.”
—being comfortable with not knowing, so you can wade deeper into genuinely unknown territory where discoveries happen.
: “Here’s the method, here’s the data, follow these steps, get the right answer”
: “Here’s an interesting phenomenon - figure out how to study it”
: “Use this specific software package exactly as shown”
: “Choose appropriate tools, adapt them to your needs, integrate multiple approaches”
: “Learn from mistakes - they’re how discoveries happen”
Many courses accidentally teach students to:
Wait for instructions rather than taking initiative
Focus on “what does the professor want?” rather than “what does this result mean?”
Avoid risks that might lead to interesting discoveries
See confusion as failure rather than the beginning of understanding
This doesn’t prepare you for careers where creativity and independent thinking are essential.
: Research supervisors expect you to contribute ideas, not just follow directions. You need to develop intellectual confidence and curiosity.
: By explicitly rewarding thinking over compliance, you develop the mindset essential for research success.
: Research involves constant learning, failed experiments, and iterative improvement. Perfection paralysis kills creativity.
: You develop resilience and learn to extract value from challenges rather than avoiding them.

: Real research requires going beyond minimum requirements to discover something new or interesting. Each project includes mandatory extensions (parameter exploration, visualization interpretation, performance analysis) that push you to experiment.
: You practice the curiosity and initiative that drives scientific discovery, learning to ask “what if?” and “why does this happen?”
: AI tools are now standard in computational research, but using them effectively requires critical thinking and domain expertise.
: You learn to leverage AI strategically while maintaining the deep understanding needed for research innovation.
: Modern research is highly collaborative, requiring effective communication and mutual learning.
: You develop skills for working productively with peers, giving and receiving feedback, and learning from others.
: Ting & O’Briain (2025) conducted an empirical study of LLM integration in final-year undergraduate astronomy education and found:
Students decreased their AI dependence over time
when given structured guidance and documentation requirements
AI became a learning tool rather than a shortcut
- students developed verification workflows instead of just seeking answers
- students became better at evaluating AI strengths and limitations
: Students reported high confidence that the AI literacy skills would be valuable for future academic and professional work
: Contrary to fears about AI undermining education,
thoughtful integration with reflection requirements actually enhanced learning outcomes while building essential 21st-century skills.
“This seems harder than my other courses”

children.label: “This seems harder than my other courses”

children.value: : You’re developing new cognitive abilities—independent thinking, creative problem-solving, and comfort with uncertainty.
Neuroscience shows this kind of learning literally requires your brain to form new neural connections, which takes mental effort.
: Research demonstrates that students who develop a
(believing abilities can be developed through effort) significantly outperform those with a
The Ting & O’Briain study confirms that students who engage with this approach develop valuable professional skills and decreased AI dependency over time.
This is scientifically normal and valuable.
“Science involves confronting our ‘absolute stupidity’... The more comfortable we become with being stupid, the deeper we will wade into the unknown.”
: Mistakes and confusion during learning signal that your brain is actively building new neural pathways.
The productive struggle is where cognitive growth happens—avoiding it means avoiding the development of expertise.
: Reading, writing, debugging, and adapting computational methods
: Communicating your approach clearly for future reference
: Choosing appropriate approaches for specific questions
: Understanding what computational outputs mean physically
: Recognizing boundaries and assumptions in your work
: Presenting complex ideas clearly to technical audiences
: Acknowledging what you don’t know and where you’re uncertain
: Working effectively with peers at similar skill levels
: Learning from feedback and iterating on your approach
How This Prepares You for Success

children.label: How This Prepares You for Success

children.value: : Research experience, genuine computational competency, ability to articulate how you learn from challenges
: Independence in tackling problems, creative approaches, meaningful team contributions
: Clear communication of complex work to funding agencies
: Debug complex systems, write maintainable code, integrate AI tools strategically
: Approach novel datasets, develop custom pipelines, interpret results for stakeholders
: Develop and validate models under uncertainty, communicate findings to decision-makers
: Translate technical capabilities into user-facing solutions
: Build prototypes, evaluate feasibility, pivot based on data
: Connect technical work to broader business goals
: Guide projects and mentor others in technical contexts
: Approach novel challenges systematically across any domain
: Evaluate complex information and make reasoned decisions
: Acquire new skills independently throughout your career
: Explain complex ideas clearly to diverse audiences
: Persist through difficult problems and learn from setbacks
: Use AI tools effectively while maintaining critical judgment
Making the Most of This Approach

children.label: Making the Most of This Approach

children.value: Feeling challenged or uncertain is a sign you’re growing. Research careers require comfort with ambiguity and confidence in your ability to figure things out.
: Perfect for working through challenges collaboratively
: Learn from peers and contribute to their learning
: Reflect on your development and consolidate insights
Individual assignments matter less than the cumulative development of your capabilities. Ask yourself: “How am I growing as a computational scientist?”
This is your education and your career - I’m just here to provide opportunities.
You get to decide how much you want to engage with this approach and what you want to get out of it.
to develop independence, creativity, and critical thinking
that serve you across academic and industry careers
as you develop your own problem-solving capabilities
where intellectual risk-taking is safe and encouraged
- how deeply you dive into optional explorations and growth opportunities
- what skills and insights you prioritize developing
- whether you pursue academia, industry, entrepreneurship, or something entirely different
- whether you see them as obstacles or growth opportunities
: Meet the requirements, pass the course, move on with your degree
: Use this as an opportunity to develop stronger problem-solving and technical skills
: Let this fundamentally change how you approach learning and professional challenges
All of these are valid choices.
I hope you’ll choose deeper engagement because I believe it will serve you well, but ultimately that’s your decision to make.

The skills we’re developing here - independent thinking, creative problem-solving, strategic AI use, intellectual resilience - are increasingly valuable across all technical careers. Whether you become a researcher, data scientist, software engineer, consultant, or entrepreneur, these capabilities will serve you.
But you’re the one who has to live your career and make your own choices about what matters to you.
I’m here to provide opportunities and support. What you do with them is entirely up to you.
- Everyone feels lost the first 2-3 weeks. This is your brain building new neural pathways.
- Wrestling with problems before seeking help builds problem-solving muscles.
- They’re for your development, not performance evaluation.
- You’re only 4 students—leverage each other’s strengths.
Come to Hacking Hours with specific questions
- “I tried X, expected Y, got Z” is much better than “I’m stuck.”
Add “yet” to your struggles: “I don’t understand this YET”
Reframe errors as data: “Interesting, why did that break?”
Celebrate productive failures: “I learned three ways that don’t work”
Value questions over answers: “What am I not seeing here?”

This course requires ~9 hours per week outside of class, though you may spend more time early in the semester as you develop your skills and confidence. That’s not punishment—it’s practice time for developing expertise. Like learning an instrument or training for athletics, computational thinking requires consistent daily practice, not last-minute cramming. As you build competency, you’ll work more efficiently.
You’re not just learning to code. You’re learning to think like a computational scientist.
